ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

At what age did you start becoming bilingual?
At what age would you class yourself as bilingual?
How would you describe your current language use?
Notes: 1 = Primarily one language; 2 = Use two or more languages but in different settings (i.e. one on the phone with my grandparents and one with work); 3 = Use both languages every day within the same setting

ElementDescription: When I talk to people at home I use more than one language, e.g. When I talk to my dad, I use both Spanish and English: 'I went for a walk today', 'Dãnde estö el perro'

When I talk to people at home I use words in another language than the one I am currently speaking in, e.g. I say 'My new flatmate is amable' (either because I can't find the word in that language or the other word came first)
When I talk to people at home I begin a sentence in one language and finish it in another, e.g. 'Tomar_ prestada tu pluma, if you don't mind'

When I talk to people at home I mix languages within one word, i.e. I blend a Spanish word ending with an English word, or vice versa, e.g. 'dame los löpizs por favor' 'Take the road with lots of zigzagues till you reach a gate'
When I talk to people at work I use more than one language, e.g. When I talk to my supervisor, I use both Spanish and English: 'I went for a walk today', 'Dãnde estö el perro'

When I talk to people at work I use words in another language than the one I am currently speaking in, e.g. I say 'My new colleague is amable' (either because I can't find the word in that language or the other word came first)
When I talk to people at work I begin a sentence in one language and finish it in another, e.g. 'Tomar_ prestada tu pluma, if you don't mind'

When I talk to people at work I mix languages within one word, i.e. I blend a Spanish word ending with an English word, or vice versa, e.g. 'dame los löpizs por favor' 'Take the road with lots of zigzagues till you reach a gate'
When I talk to people when socializing I use more than one language, e.g. When I talk to my friend, I use both Spanish and English: 'I went for a walk today', 'Dãnde estö el perro'

When I talk to people when socializing I use words in another language than the one I am currently speaking in, e.g. I say 'My new colleague is amable' (either because I can't find the word in that language or the other word came first)
When I talk to people when socializing I begin a sentence in one language and finish it in another, e.g. 'Tomar_ prestada tu pluma, if you don't mind'

When I talk to people when socializing I mix languages within one word, i.e. I blend a Spanish word ending with an English word, or vice versa, e.g. 'dame los löpizs por favor' 'Take the road with lots of zigzagues till you reach a gate'
Non-English Home Use and Proficiency Score
Notes: Higher score indicates greater second language proficiency and use in private life, home, etc. As described in LSBQ Factor Score Calculator.xlsx, 10.6084/m9.figshare.3972486.v5; Factor 1 score

ElementDescription: Non-English Social Use Score.
Notes: Higher score indicates more second language use in societal and community contexts. As described in LSBQ Factor Score Calculator.xlsx, 10.6084/m9.figshare.3972486.v5; Factor 2 score

ElementDescription: English Proficiency Score.
Notes: Higher score indicates more english proficiency. As described in LSBQ Factor Score Calculator.xlsx, 10.6084/m9.figshare.3972486.v5; Factor 3 score

ElementDescription: Composite Factor Score.
Notes: Higher score indicates bilingualism. As described in LSBQ Factor Score Calculator.xlsx; Composite factor score
